title.value: Predicting the Population Risk of Suicide Using Routinely Collected Health Administrative Data in Quebec, Canada: Model-Based Synthetic Estimation Study
title.justification: The title of the paper precisely describes the study, which aims to predict the population risk of suicide using health administrative data in Quebec.
title.quote: Predicting the Population Risk of Suicide Using Routinely Collected Health Administrative Data in Quebec, Canada: Model-Based Synthetic Estimation Study

extractions.description: The paper aims to develop and validate prediction models for assessing the population risk of suicide using routinely collected health administrative data in Quebec, Canada. It uses logistic regression models to create sex-specific synthetic estimation models based on individual, health system, and community-level predictors.

type.justification: The study involves data collection, application of logistic regression models, and evaluation of model performance, which indicates that it is an empirical study.
type.quote: We used a case-control study design to develop sex-specific risk prediction models for suicide, using the health administrative data in Quebec, Canada.

name.justification: The research is primarily focused on developing predictive models for estimating population risk of suicide, a significant public health issue.
name.quote: The aim of this study was to develop and validate sex-specific predictive models for the population risk of suicide based on individual, health system–, and community-level indicators in Quebec, Canada.

name.justification: The paper deals with the study of the distribution and determinants of health states in populations, focusing on suicide risk prediction.
name.quote: This study aims to develop and validate prediction models for the population risk of suicide using health administrative data, considering individual-, health system–, and community-level predictors.

name.justification: The study directly addresses suicide, a critical aspect of mental health, by using administrative data for risk prediction.
name.quote: This study demonstrated the feasibility and the validity of developing prediction models for population risk of suicide, incorporating individual-, health system–, and community-level variables.

name.justification: The paper describes using logistic regression models to develop sex-specific synthetic prediction models for suicide risk.
name.quote: Logistic regression was used to develop the prediction models based on individual-, health care system–, and community-level predictors.

is_contributed.justification: The logistic regression model is a key component introduced in this study for suicide risk prediction.
is_contributed.quote: Logistic regression was used to develop the prediction models based on individual-, health care system–, and community-level predictors.

is_executed.justification: The model was trained and validated using health administrative data from Quebec, indicating execution.
is_executed.quote: The developed model was converted into synthetic estimation models, which concerted the individual-level predictors into community-level predictors.

is_compared.justification: There is no indication in the provided text that the model was numerically compared to other models.
is_compared.quote: We assessed the performance of the synthetic estimation models with four indicators.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no reference to another paper for the logistic regression model used in this study.

name.justification: These datasets provided the primary data source for developing the prediction model.
name.quote: We linked 5 health administrative databases using residents’ health care insurance numbers and the Canadian Urban Environmental Health Research (CANUE) data by postal codes, including the vital statistics death database, the physician claims database, the hospital discharge database, the Insured Person Registration File, and the public drug plan.

referenced_paper_title.justification: These databases are used as the primary data resource but do not reference a specific paper.
